title: A Sturdier and Still Cheap Filament Turntable

description.text:
This is a derivative work of my previous "A Very Cheap Filament Turntable"
The previous worked fine, but I got local supply for my ABS filament, and it's rolled in a larger diameter. Instead of cutting a bigger piece of cardboard, I decided it's time to make it sturdier.

• Make a hole in the center of the plastic saucer (punch, drill, whatever.) The hole should be able to let your bolt through. You can replace the saucer with an expanded polystyrene container comes with one's birthday cake, but ABS washers will be suggested in this case.
  • Fix the bolt on the saucer with 2 nuts. I added an ABS washer, but it's optional. The weight of the filament roll applies only on the marbles, the bolt is to keep the turning centered.
    2.1 If you use expanded polystyrene container instead, you might want to print 2 ABS washers and sandwich the expanded polystyrene container with them.
  • Put the CD case up-side-down, and place glass marbles on the gutters. (Most pudding cases should have a gutter in the back, some of my 50-disks cases don't, and they can't stand still up-side-down, either.)
  • Have the saucer sit on top of the marbles with the bolt in the center hole. Voila, you've got a very sturdy turntable.
  • I use a 3M command adhesive thing on the wall for filament guide. It worked perfect.

description.text:
This is a moveable holster. The idea is for the user to nail it to the wall slightly above and behind the 3D printer.
The way it works is the user will nail the core and the wall lock (a little lower) behind the 3D printer on the wall. You then slide the spool onto the ends of the spinners. You then screw the screw stop onto the screw and then screw the screw into the top of the cylinder (finger tight). Repeat for all spools, or until out of holsters.
Then let the desired holster spin to the bottom.
Insert the stopper into the wall lock so that the spinner core won't spin anymore.
Lock that with the lock.
Connect your filament to the printer and you are ready to print.
(all names are according to the files)

You will have to print multiple copies of the screw and screw stop.
You need your own nails for the wall

title: Da Vinci Calibration Mount (Using Retaining Clips from original packaging)

description.text:
Simple mount which can be glued directly to the packing clips that secure your extruder head when you unpack machine, these were made to measure and a perfect fit so why re invent the wheel.
One short M3.5 machine screw and nut to secure not really necessary at first but after several uses could be needed. A dab of either Super glue, 99% Acetone or PVC/ABS pipe weld to attach the printed plate to retaining clips. Sized to fit the Silverline 0-10mm Metric Dial Indicator which I obtained from amazon for under £8 makes calibration a doddle.

Hello my friend  
I designed a turntable to hold a coil for 3D printing, I thought many people would make designs to save many coils, but I decided to design a project to save a coil but stylish.  
Also I think it is an object of decoration, and can camouflage in a room and not attract attention.  
I hope you like it and give me your opinion :)

Steps 1-4 Together the four pieces that we use as a base, and include some details on the right following the order of the images. Steps 5-8 Add the center to give a central detail, and add a piece that is designed to pass the thread under it.
Also we part together in front of the disk and add touches designs buttons, and once done move individually. Steps 9-12 Place the front part within the rectangle you have made the base, and fit perfectly. (Part 9 download)
Add the four part forming a circle, if together four and introduce them see how the cylinder with pressure from above and being inside the base can not be moved, therefore act as a unique piece that will stand for the spool. It is designed so you can move the needle is on the coil if you want to change and be supported. Pasos 1-4 Juntamos las cuatro piezas que usamos como base, y incluimos algunos detalles de la parte derecha siguiendo el orden de las imágenes. Pasos 5-8 Añadimos la parte central para darle un detalle central, y añadimos una pieza que está diseñada para que pase el filamento por debajo de ella.
Además juntamos la parte delante del toca disco y le añadimos los diseños de botones, y una vez hecho esto se mueven individualmente. Pasos 9-12 Colocamos la parte delante dentro del rectángulo que tiene hecho la base, y encajará perfectamente. Añadimos las cuatro parte que forman una circunferencia (piezas en la descarga (9)), si juntas las cuatro e introduces en ellas los cilindro verás como al presionarlas desde arriba y al estar dentro de la base no se podrá mover, por lo tanto actuarán como una única pieza que será el soporte para que la bobina gire. Está diseñado para que puedas mover la "aguja" que está sobre la bobina si quieres cambiarla y quedará apoyada.

comments.text: Didn't come out at all.
comments.author: MakerBlock

comments.text: Okay, chances are that the wall was too thin.  Try to make that wall the same thickness or very slightly thicker than your thread thickness setting in Skeinforge
comments.author: royshearer

comments.text: would that be in carve/layer thickness? I have that setting at 0.4 which is roughly what I expected, hence my thin walls were set to 0.5mm.
comments.author: MakerBlock

comments.text: Not really.  It's my fault for not being clear.  Layer thickness is the thickness of the layers of plastic that are laid down.  A typical profile will have layers of about 0.3-0.4mm depending upon your nozzle, etc.  What I meant to refer to was the thread width.  This is how wide the strand of plastic is when it comes out of the nozzle.  A typical profile will have thread width of about 0.5-0.8mm, depending upon a variety of factors.  Amusingly, there's no place to look this up in Skeinforge.  However, if you know your "W/T" or "Width over Thickness" variables (this is entered several times throughout Skeinforge, and you know your layer thickness, you can solve for thread width.

author: REDANT01

description.text: I really, really, REALLY wish that MakerWare had a skirt function like Skeinforge in ReplicatorG. I love the freedom of being able to set up my build plate without having the go into my CAD program to create a "plate" to use in RepG. Yes, I know you can set up Skeinforge profiles in MakerWare but to be honest I really can't stand the time it takes to slice using those profiles and to be honest I like, more times than not, how the print come out using MakerWare. While trying to print a large object using the Help Disks provided in MakerWare and trying to find a way to create a skirt it hit me. Why not just put a disk closest the the left/front corner of the build plate and let it print that first to get the filament going before it goes on the the real stuff. I am in no way stating that I created these items. I'm just reposting them on here just in case. They can also be found under "Examples" in MakerWare UPDATE: FYI This is pretty much obsolete with the new version of MakerWare. The new version makes a really nice long anchor at the very front of the build plate that pretty much does the same thing as this disk

It's Simple:

  • place your objects on the plate in MakerWare.

  • place a helper disk in the lower left of the plate (Would be the front of the build plate)

  • Love life!

comments.text: thanks mate you have made my night, i was googling if their was such a feature to add a skirt around a raftless print in makerbot desktop. a small helper disc in the front corner done the trick,

This is a filament spool holder which can be a multi spool holder for more than 2 or 3 spools (picture 5). For the basic variant (picture 3) you need:
  • 2x baseplates

  • 2x foot 1
  • 1x foot 2

For this you don´t need the foots but if you wish to make it safer you need 1x the "protection for lying construction". To build it please use the pictures as a plan. I hope you understanding all and wish you best of luck for printing and building. Read Instructions for a good print. If you have got a question about printing or building please send me a message.

title: FlashForge Creator Pro 2015 universal spool holder by Nas

description.text:
This is a Universal FlashForge creator pro spool holder designed for the models that have a slot where the holder clamps.  This design should fit any spool size and diameter.  The closing mechanism is based on a cone, where the spool rests, pushing it downwards and locking it into place using slots.  The closing cone piece will rotate but won't be able to exit the holder until an upward force is exerted.  This is my second version and it works flawlessly.  The diameter of the spool holder is 19 mm and the length is 110 mm.  The closing cone larger diameter is 56 mm.  All my spools fit with these dimensions, even the new Octave 3DP very small spool hole of 20 mm.  
This FF spool holder was inspired by two creations: Thing 714533 by davedfx and Thing 508896 by CreativeTools.  I didn't want to use metal screws like other designs, so I redesigned a holder with slots with a larger cone that due to the weight of the spool will lock into place but it is free to rotate (instead of using a threaded design which will not work for this application).   
Please check it and let me know if it works for you.  
UPDATE: added an optional washer for large diameter spools, so that the internal washer cone also rotates minimizing the friction (this washer enters the spool holder before the filament spool).  This is an additional part that doesn't change the previous design.  
UPDATE 2: added a new second closing cone with a larger end diameter to accommodate spools with diameters up to 60 mm.  The new external larger end diameter of this cone is 67 mm.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30%

Notes: The main mount cylinder has to be printed on its side (as it is positioned in the photo with the wood background) with supports and the cone printed with its longer diameter towards the print table. I used 30% infill and three perimeters to be sure it will be solid. I didn't use supports to print the cone and reduced the infill to 20% and two perimeters.

comments.text: Thanks, do you use supports for the cones?
comments.author: nas7

comments.text: Good question.  I didn't, but the cone internal threads need to be straight and parallel for the best mesh.  Some of the persons that reported their prints used supports and other didn't and almost all of them reported success.  Check the comments and parameters they have used in each of the "Made" reports for this design.  I think it will depend on the plastic quality, temperature and speed to get it right without support.  However if you use support and define them so small that the supports are created inside the threads you will have problems trying to get them all out.  My recommendation will be not to use supports or to define supports that are easy to get out (only to provide support at the center of the hole for instance).  My cones printed at the first attempt and they didn't have issues meshing.  Please let me know your experience and please post your print and comments so that others can benefit with your test.
comments.author: totalitarian

comments.text: I printed this on a Flashforge Creator Pro using the recommended settings.  The threads inside the cone didn't come out very well - it does not thread onto the other piece properly. comments.text: It is difficult to know what is the problem in your case.  In my tests, the threads fit nicely.  Maybe different kind of filaments? (I did mine with ABS).  You could try to print the cone with support generation, so that the threads won't deform inside (although it will be probably difficult to remove the supports) or try to change the print parameters (speed maybe?) to get the inside threads right.  The tolerance is tight for the fit to get the most surface for support.  Please let me know if you print additional tests and solve the issue.  I could try to modify the design to allow for more tolerance.

comments.text: Printed a second holder. Had problems with fit, until I tried a different Creator Pro (I have two in my classroom). It fit perfectly fine in the second one. title: Geeetech Prusa i3c Dual J-head mount

description.text:
A simple dual J-Head replacement mount for the original Geeetech dual motor carriage design. Mine warped from heat, weight of 2 motors, and being built of PLA material. This may work with other printers by drilling a hole or 2 in the mounting plate.
The back plate is tapered, allowing better airflow and fan positioning.
Using 2 of the square adapter blocks. It is relatively simple to adapt the original extruder feed motors, to a bowden connector. This was created with a cad program, using inches. Providing several file options but scad is not one. So I don't have a .scad to share.

Import in inches. Using the original 4m x 35m screws, this mounts fine with or without nuts. After a few heat cycles it will loosen, so use nuts to permanently install the body. For the clamp, you will need two or three, 3m x 20m or longer, screws. No nuts required. But you may want to drill the clamp, screw holes, as they are fairly snug. To allow for height adjustment, the right clamp has no center alignment ridge.
Install the center screw to hold the clamp and print heads in place. Intentionally leaving the right head higher than the left. Zero out the left Print head then adjust the Right head down to match. Lock them all down with the center and right screws.
Confirm the Y-axis alignment against the leading edge of your print surface.
You can check and adjust your alignment using this calibration chip. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1008954 An X-axis offset of 30.1625mm or 1.1875" for the second extruder. YMMV Double check your nozzle spacing to confirm, and adjust accordingly. This is my first thing. Advice and suggestions welcome
Thanks

title: HANGING FILAMENT RACK
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
THIS ITEM DESIGNED FOR THE MAKERBOT FILAMENT CHALLENGE. The idea was to make something:
  • everyone with a 3d printer could make. Largest part required will fit on a
    75x75x95 mm machine.
  • affordable. What good does a filament rack do you if you burn up all your filament making it. This design only uses 70 grams of filament to make a set for 2 spools.
  • different. There are dozens of desk top storage solutions but who has extra desktop space. This item was designed to hang in a closet. With a 60" hanging bar you can put 12 rolls in 7" of space.
  • configurable. Using the optional parts you can convert your closet hanger to a wall hanger. If you have wider roles there are
    parts for 3" 4" & 5" wide spools.
  • scale-able. Hang as many as you need. Even in pla this was designed tough. You'll run out of height before strength.
  • tool-less design. No tools required to assemble.
    • Be sure to read instructions for important notes:

Select which Item you want to make. Closet rod hanging uses:
1 - SIDE-A
1 - SIDE-B
2 - CAP-3.0
NOTE:
(if your spool is 4" wide use CAP4.0 if its 5" use CAP5.0 )
To Better Secure your spindles a extra large cap is available. Wall Hanging unit uses
1 - SIDE-A
1 - COVER
1 - CAP-3.0 . Parts printed at :
layer .250
infill 20%
2 walls, 2 Bottom and 3 Top.
use support on Side - A and Side B ASSEMBLY.
(NOTE this was designed to be used with 1/4" rope)
I have also tested it with cat5 cable. and some old phone cable. Secure one end of your rope to the bar in your closet. Move down about 5" from your board and thread the rope through the back of SIDE A so it enters one side and leaves the other.
Make sure it is not real loose . Slide Side B over the the Back of Side A. Make sure to do this from the top. Screw the Caps on to both ends that are required for your filament. Rack works best when spools are stored in pairs. For better results a weight can be put at the bottom of the string. For Wall Mounting: For wall Rack Secure your spindles at 9" apart on the rope . Secure rope to the wall at the bottom and the top.

author: tamberg

description.text:
These are simple stepper motor brackets for equatorial telescope mounts. My telescope mount  is unbranded and inexpensive. I do not know if the brackets will fit other types. The brackets are for Nema 17 type stepper motors. The equatorial drive should be a 0.9deg per step motor if you intend to use it for astrophotography. Keep your expectations and magnification low as direct driven mounts have limitations.  
If you use the bracket for the declination axis you will have to use screws that are 3-4 mm longer than original. If you use a dual shaft motor on the declination axis you can put a knob at the back of it for manual adjustment if you are out of batteries. The motors will of course require some sort of controller. I plan to use an arduino with A4988 Stepper Motor Driver Modules at 1/8 steps.  
It is generally not recommended to mount your telescope without counterweights.
The controls on the box are a four axis (well, three and a button) joystick for two axis and focus, the button is to enable, There is also a rotary encoder for fine tuning  the equatorial and focus drive and an on-off-on spring return toggle switch to choose which. All from ebay. The focus drive is mounted on a metal angle not shown.
I hope to add the arduino sketch when it is ready.

I used ABS in 0.3mm layers.
All screws in the controllerbox are 12mm M3 nylon. It takes three A4988 stepper motor drive modules and an arduino nano. I use drilled out M3 nylon nuts as spacers for the modules. The holes in the cable tentioner must be threaded with a tap.

title: Betrayal at House on the Hill Organizer

description.text: I am always making small improvements to this design so if you have any changes that you think would improve it please let me know and I will try to get get those added as soon as possible UPDATE 2: Adjusted the tolerances again to make the two parts twist together easier. Shout out to Sigismond0 who designed a cover for the top half to keep pieces from falling out when the box is stored on its side which can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1435061 UPDATE 1: I added a cutout to the top piece to make the squares in the center to easier to remove and adjusted the underside to make it printable without any supports. Adjusted the tolerances so the two pieces fit together better and don't come apart as easily. While playing Betrayal with some friends we found it really hard to keep track of the 200+ little pieces that are used throughout the game. Because the pieces are so small and many are rarely used, it is easy to lose them and often takes a long time to find the pieces you need when the game requires them. This two part print consists of a circular base with slots to fit all of the small monster tokens used during the haunt as well as a large hole in the middle designed to hold the trait markers or paper clips that we like to use instead. The top piece has slots for the more commonly used tokens such as the large monsters and random event tokens. The two pieces fit together to stay in one piece and were designed to fit in the large bowl shaped holder of the second generation box. I've never seen a first printing box but hopefully they are the same.

comments.text: I've been waiting for someone to mention the counterclockwise thing. I noticed that when I first printed it off and put it together but never got around to actually going back and fixing it. As for the clearance issue, its designed to be pretty tight but should still work. Some printers print an extra wide base layer so you might just have to widen out the pocket on the bottom of the top piece a little bit with a hobby knife or something to get it to fit. I also had a weird issue on some prints where the two pieces would only fit together in one configuration so try lining it up with different tabs and see if it will fit together then.

? ? ?

Again - brilliant work thanks for all you time and effort.

Here's a filament holder to show off your maker pride! One side says "Heart of a Maker," and the other side says "Make Your Heart Out." This five-piece model holds a regular 1kg filament spool.   
Here's the story:  
As soon as I saw this challenge I was inspired to make a filament holder celebrating makers!  The challenge for me was designing one that would print on my Printrbot Play, which has a build dimension of 10x10x13 cm, which is too small to make a two-piece standard-sized filament holder. So I tackled my printer constraints by designing a multi-piece holder with pieces that fit nicely into each other. I designed it in Tinkercad.  
My design incorporates printability on a small printer and maker swag!  
The filament holder in the images is blue 1.75mm PLA.

• Print one 'Heart of a Maker' side and one 'Make Your Heart Out' side. For both, you'll need to have support material enabled everywhere. Make sure to remove the support material with needle-nosed pliers in the cylinder support holes.

  • Print the 'end holder for cylinder.'

  • Print the 'cylinder and end.'

  • Print the 'flat bottom' piece.

  • Time for assembly: you'll need some super glue or other tough adhesive. First, glue the 'end holder for cylinder' into the 'make your heart out' side.

  • Position the 'make your heart out' and 'heart of a maker' sides on the flat bottom piece and glue them in place. You should now have both sides standing up.

  • Finally, load your spool onto the remaining piece, the 'cylinder and end.' lower the spool into place, but do not glue, as you won't be able to remove your filament spool. To change your filament, just lift the spool straight up, change spools, and position back into place.

  • Volià! You now have the heart of a maker for making your heart out with such an awesome spool holder! :)
    • Note: If printing with the Printrbot Play, like I did, make sure you disable the skirt for the two sides so that they fit on the print bed. I set the infill for the whole thing at an average of 10%, with the cylinder piece at 25% for extra strength.

The motor mount is quite a structural weak point on the Diatone FPV250 frame. If you have broken the arm or the motor mount, you can print this support plate to fix it.  
You will need 4 M3x20mm screws to attach the plate to the frame and 4 M3x10mm scews to attach the motor to the plate.  
(Or just improvise and use zipties/glue/whatever...)  
Print @ 100% infill.

description.text: More than ten hours of design were put to make this awesome spool holder look sexy next to your Makerbot printer. But this thing wouldn't be awesome if it only had good looks. Inspired from roll holding mechanisms used in the packaging industry, the Shaftless Spool Holder minimizes the time required to mount and unmount your filament spools, allowing you to increase your production of plastic trinkets to give out as presents to your friends instead of buying them actual gifts! If things weren't perfect already, this spool holder is fully printable. I printed mine in about 8 hours at 300 microns and 8% infill. You can probably print it much faster because you are such a boss when it comes to 3D printing.

Look at you reading instructions! I printed mine in about 8 hours at 300 microns and 8% infill. It is very important you stick with 8% infill. Actually it is not. I was just running low on filament. Actually you might want to print the lead screw with 50% infill or more. Oh and you don't need supports either, they're gross.

description.text: This case is designed to hold two fountain pens. The dimensions for the slots are taken from a Lamy Al-Star and should fit most standard sized fountain pens.

Mr. Roboto is the coolest spool holder around! This design was extremely complex to construct, yet it is effectively simple and efficient in doing what its made to do! I designed every aspect of the holder, using combinations of 3D shapes to form the creation, then I added touches to make the holder work to the best of its ability while still maintaining its cool look. I have designed the holder to hold a variety of spool shapes and sizes. It can hold spools with:
  • an outer diameter of up to 18cm
  • a width of up to 6.2cm
  • a mount hole diameter as little as 3cm
    • Mr. Roboto also has a feed where the filament goes through keeping it untangled and on the right path! (It dispenses from the middle of the triangle) Build your own Mr. Roboto Spool Holder now! :D

• Look at instruction picture
    • To build the spool holder simply thread the filament through the thread hole (look at red arrow: thread through back of head), put the cylinder spool holder through the filament spool hole (add the stability rings on either end depending on the width of the filament spool: blue arrow). Then place the cylinder spool holder in the slot of Mr. Robotos head (purple arrow) Simple as ! :)

This is an upgrade for the Thing-O-Matic Mk7 Extruder. Features:
  • Easy filament swap
  • Open drive wheel for easy cleaning
  • Bearing idler
  • The non-printable parts are easy to source
  • Adjustable idler pressure
  • Quick to print
    • I created this b/c I was having some issues with the plunger pressure not being adjustable. I didn't want to go with some of the other designs on here b/c of the difficulty of adjusting tension or the difficultly of sourcing exactly the correct springs. Additionally, some of the really nice extruders out there are HUGE! I didn't want to spend hours printing and potentially lose the print on a faulty plunger. For the full troubleshooting story, check out the blog entry, http://slightlynybbled.blogspot.com/2015/09/makerbot-extruder-woes-and-successes.html Additional notes:
  • I have made a few minor upgrades to the assembly since printing my version. I had a small crash near the lower right, but not enough to cause an actual problem. I have since raised the spring assembly 0.1".
  • This part is inspired by many things I have seen on thingiverse. I couldn't begin to name them all.
  • Basic design should be easy to adapt to other spring and bearing sizes.
  • I know that it appears as though there is a high-friction surface between the base and arm. In fact, the two do come into contact, but there is a very small bevel around the rotation point that ensures that the parts do not have a large contact area. Movement is easy and smooth.
  • I am supporting feed rates of 55mm/s on my ToM. I don't want to damage anything, so I probably won't go much higher than this. Post in the comments if you are printing faster with this extruder design!
  • I don't have a dual-extruder setup to test with, but I suspect that these parts could easily be mirrored for those types of applications. Drop me a line if you want to give it a shot and I can mirror the parts for you.
  • If you have a different set of springs - say, 1" or 1.5", drop a line in the comments and I can remix this easily enough. Just send the COMPLETE spring dimensions (hole sizes at the ends, length when extended, and width).

Things to purchase:
  • 2" tension springs (easy to find at Lowes or Home Depot for a couple of bucks)
  • Bearing, 10mm OD, 3mm ID, 4mm Depth (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008DSKCI6?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00)
    • Instructions correspond to the order of the pictures.
  • Print your parts. The file "extruder_printable_all.STL" contains the entire assembly. Individual parts are also supplied as STL files. I printed with 20% fill, you probably want to go with something like 40%. I had some acceptable bending, but would have been happier with a stiffer assembly. There is also a small chamfered overhang on the "bearing_clamp.STL" file. This overhang should be easily printed on most machines.
  • Disassemble your stock Mk7 extruder. Keep the flat-head screws. You won't need to remove your filament.
  • Assemble the bearing to the extruder arm. Place the extruder arm on the extruder base.
  • Place the bearing clamp over the bearing bore insert. Depending on your print settings, you may need to bore this out slightly. I like to print my first layer a bit smashed, so the hole was slightly small on the 1st layer surface. Press the bearing clamp all the way down, it should require some force since the small overhangs on the edges are meant to hold tight to the sides. My parts didn't require any trimming or post-processing to achieve a nice fit.
  • Apply the flat-head screw through all three printed parts. It should fit snugly. The arm motion should be clearly articulated around the screw at this point.
  • Place the assembly on your motor, tighten the right screw a bit, and use the other flathead screw on the left side. Tighten both screws firmly, but you don't need a lot of force.
  • Place the spring(s) on the right side. Make adjustments by adding/removing springs and by moving springs in or out.
  • Re-assemble the fan to the front of the extruder.
    • Happy printing!

description.text: A very simple spool holder made for printers on shelves, under hutches, etc. This can hold two spools, although it would be a tight fit (or you can just print it bigger). It can be fastened to a shelf one of two ways: (a) using the hole in the top, screw it into the shelf (wood shelf) or zip-tie it to the shelf (wire shelf), or (b) using the notches on the sides and hook on the top, tie it to the shelf, looping around the back (this is the method I used).

This is meant to be printed without support, although a raft is recommended. I printed it at 0.3 mm resolution.  
Once it is printed, attach the ends to your shelf and simply snap the rod into place while the spool is on it. The flat side helps with both printing and snapping the rod into place.

description.text: This will cradle a reel type filament spool allowing smooth unreeling while printing. This will hold the small spools that T-Glase comes on all the way up to the large spools most filament comes on. NOTE: This is marked as a work in progress as the bearings I used came preassembled with the grooved spindle from Vetco.net. This design is fully functional but requires these grooved spindles. They are the primary design feature that makes these functional. I have included a piece that is the spindle that will fit a standard 608 bearing. If you find my designs useful, please help by donating.

This will require the following, but may vary depending on the bearings you use... (2) printed base parts, they are symmetrical
(4) bearings 608, (mine came from Vetco.net with spindle)
(4) printed spindles, (if your bearings did not come with them already)
(4) bolts, M8 40mm
(4) lock nuts, M8
(8) flat washers, M8 If you printed the bearing spindle, then you will need to press the bearing into the spindle from the beveled side until it is centered, which should be all the way against the inner race of opening. Make sure to assemble with the flat washers sandwiching the bearing. Tighten so the bearing doesn't rock and rotates freely. The spool sides rest into the groves of the bearing spindles.

title: 9 mm Chamber Safety Flag for Glock handgun ( press check )

description.text: Even if a gun doesn't have a magazine it could still have a bullet in the chamber and it is potentially dangerous, there is no indication in most guns to check if there is a live round on the gun, the user must then operate the gun in order to make sure is safe. Remember to always perform multiple safety checks on any gun you need to handle. A Chamber Safety Flag is a tool which indicates that a weapon is unloaded and is safe to manipulate ( press check ) , it allow anyone who sees the gun to know that the gun has no live round and unable load and shoot. - See more at: http://www.libremechanics.com/?q=node/36 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hmgCvQxB8_w

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Always print the Chamber Safety Flag in a vivid color different from the color of the gun or its surroundings to improve recognition and a infill of 100% it's recommended to ensure resistance. - See more at: http://www.libremechanics.com/?q=node/36

comments.text: while every weapon should always be treated as if it is loaded... Glocks do have an external indicator on if their is a round in the chamber or not.  The extractor is flush with the body when there isn't a round in the chamber, and it extrudes slightly when there is.

description.text:
This was designed with a few things in mind. First: Relatively minimal amount of material (to do this I opted to use string for a portion of the support between the two printed pieces).
Second: Accessibility to individual spools (I wanted the ability to easily add or remove spools which were not in use without the need to displace more than one spool at a time).
Third: A way to prevent spools that were not in use from unwinding everywhere. One additional consideration was the ability to store spools tightly packed together. I have 15 filament spools atm, stacked in 3-4 piles on the living-room floor of my apartment. A large portion of the goal of this design is to move them away from my floor... A Couple of Notes: I printed these pieces with a 50% fill and 2mm shell thickness (as well as a raft) which took about 4 hours a piece. The parts came out significantly sturdier than I was expecting. Additionally, I could not find my spool of kite string (I moved not that long ago probably related to filament being on floor) so the "string" I used is actually a thin-gauge decorative wire and a twisty-tie.

Materials:
1x Spool Holder
1x Spool Support
Kite String (or dental floss, fishing line, thin-gauge wire, etc) Assembly:
  • Cut two pieces of string a little longer than the diameter of filament spool.
  • Take one piece of string and thread it through one of the holes in the Spool Support then tie the two ends of the string together.
  • Repeat step 2 with the other hole and other piece of string.
  • Cut a third piece of string that is 3-4 inches long.
  • Take third piece of string and thread it through one of the vertical holes in the Spool Holder, around desired support structure (dowel rod, clothes rod, towel rack, etc), then continue through the other vertical hole, tie the two ends of this string together (the grooves in the Spool Holder should face up).
  • Insert Spool Support through center of filament spool.
  • Hold the filament by the loops of string dangling from the Spool Support and loop them over the Spool Holder so that the string rests in the grooves of the Spool Holder.
  • Finally, if desired, firmly shove end of filament into one of the horizontal holes in the Spool Holder to prevent spool from unwinding while allowing easy access to the tip of the filament.
  • Admire

The vertex coordinates of the snub cube and its dual the pentagonal icositetrahedron are derived from the tribonacci constant.  Here is a composite of the two polyhedra, a bowl, and a container, all made using both sets of vertex coordinates.  Comments in the OpenSCAD program discuss the relationship between the tribonacci constant and the vertex coordinates.  It's similar to the relationship between the dodecahedron, its dual the icosihedron, and the golden ratio.

Prints of the stl files shown in the above image were done on a Replicator at a scale of 75% using 0.3 mm layers.  The lid and composite need support.  Support for the lid is limited to the rim if the support angle is set to 75 degrees.

This modular spool holder is designed to both be functional and ergonomic. The model is currently configured to take spools with a Inner diameter of 50mm using push button release mechanism.
Uses a 8mm hardware bolt and nut (not Modeled) to secure the arm to the base adapter and another to allow the spool holder to spin freely The model includes the necessary files to create several different types of spool holder including:
Single Spool
Dual Spool
With Filter (included requires glue and sponge)
Without Filter In the future i intend to upload more base designs such as bolt down ones and more compact ones. And include more spool sizes. I have been unable to test the functions of this model as i don't have a printer as yet, as such some aspects may not function as intended, the main point of concern being the spool release mechanism. So as such, print at your own risk, however let me know of any improvements you think could be made and any feedback you have Please note, printing several of the pieces for this will require supports. I also recommend if you do make this that you use an adhesive to secure the two base pieces together. ***I will be printing and modifying this design in the coming weeks to test for functionality, so stay tuned, should have this completely functional in about a month Holder Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:119016

Attach adapter piece  to base plate using an adhesive glue, 2 part epoxy, superglue etc.  
Attach chosen arm to Base assembly using an 8mm bolt of appropriate length and secure in desired position with the corresponding nut  
Attach the spool holder to the arm assembly using an 8mm partially threaded bolt inserted into the arm, through to the holder, secure this with a washer and corresponding nut . lubricate as neccesary.

description.text: Spool holder is a typical thread rod on two stands. But the multi-tool base provide you a strong base for your 3D printer to add wide variety of  gadgets (spool holders, camera, filament cleaner...)

I had problems with spool holder for long period of time but non of ideas were suitable for me. I designed a makerbot multi-tool base, that snaps on the frame of the printer, to attach a spool holder, and made it strong enough to be able to hold other things. Now anyone can make any type gadget holder or any type of spool holder and mount it on this base.

description.text:
The "baskets" on my Bass Pro Shops hiking poles (many years old) disintegrated when I used them recently; they just broke into pieces.  
So... as usual, I turned to my 3D printer.  
For these, I used PCTPE filament; a perfect material — flexible, but reasonably stiff.

As recommended on the site where I got the filament, I printed on a glass plate coated with PVA.  
I was having issues with it sticking to the print plate when heated to the recommended 45C; when I upped it to 70C, it bonded much better to the print plate (and I had more PVA).  
Fortunately, the one that did curl remained stuck well enough - at the center - for the print to complete, and the curl is actually totally ok for this part; it winds up being curved towards the ground vs. being flat.

title: Samsung Galaxy S5 Mount for Garmin Nuvi Suction Cup

description.text:
New devices come out year after year, and the accessories between  them are never compatible! Enter this adapter. This allows you to use a Samsung Galaxy S5 in an Otterbox Defender case with a Garmin Nuvi Suction Cup.  
I decided to make this after Mom got a new phone, and she does Navigation/GPS on that instead of an ancient Nuvi. So, I whipped this up so she can keep her eyes on the road instead of having to look down at it all the time.   
I took the socket part from mythbustingpyro's Defy XT mount, who remixed his from dorsch's Moto X mount. The holder for the S5 was taken from 3DPrinterNinja's S5 tripod. Both of these parts were slightly modified.  
I made this in Blender(!), and the .blend files are included for anyone who is curious. Feel free to remix this, provided you give attribution.

Option 1: (recommended)
Print out NuviBracket.stl and NuviSocket.stl (at least 30% infill). Place the socket on the back of the Bracket, and weld/glue them together. I used maurerpe's PLA welding method (in sources) to weld them together. Works great! Option 2:
Print out NuviMount.stl with support. You're done. I only prefer the first option because it takes less time to print and doesn't need as much material, because support is not needed. What method you use has no bearing on the quality of the print.

Ring

Spool Mount System  
This spool system was designed for wall-mounting a large array of spools for quick and easy access. (And who doesn't want to show off their collection?)  
With the spools mounted flush to the wall, re-winding filament after unloading is quick and precise. Spool rotation is visible from any angle at a glance to ensure the filament is feeding properly.  
Spools can be mounted to a backing board or wall in a staggered grid to maximize use of space. Sized for #6 flat screws.  
Each part of the system is optimized for sturdiness with a minimum of material, smooth spool rotation and reliable printing without any supports.  
Three different spool cores are included, sized for: MakerBot 1kg and 500g spools with a 2-inch core, plus a 3rd-party spool with a 1.5 inch core.  
The spool mount is compatible with all three cores, which fit snugly in the mount to eliminate any wobble.  
For MakerBot 1kg spools, which are more recessed at the center on one side, a “crown” offset part is also included. This is snapped onto each spool and keeps it mounted with the correct margin between it and the mounting surface consistent so the spool can be oriented for clockwise or counter-clockwise rotation.  
Tip: many spools in an array can feed filament at a good angle into the 3D printer, but to correct a steep angle of entry, the filament can be guided around adjacent spools or swapped and remounted in another position.
Designed in Foundry modo with Mesh Fusion. Prototyped and built with MakerBot Replicator 2X

author: Dufleparf

description.text: Designed to lift your filament out of the stand with great ease. Filament spool based off a Makerbot spool, yet designed to work with other spools.

This filament holder was meant to be printed without supports. "FilamentPin" and "FilamentMid" should be printed vertically to get the best results at 0.20mm height. Infill and shells vary based on preference, but I would recommend 5-10% infill and 2 shells.   
The entire print should be about 100 grams of filament.  Version 2 has been tested to work in ABS.   
Good luck printing and enjoy!

As it's name states, this is a self adjusting spring loaded spool holder. It expands in order to fit most common spools inner diameter. This is something I have been thinking for a while as an upgrade to my previous spool holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:770657 and during my previous researches stumbled upon this site/reference (http://richrap.blogspot.com/2014/03/universal-3d-printing-filament-spool.html) where they're also tackling the issue in their way. I accepted the challenge 48 hours prior it's dead line, this allowed me to learn more about rhino and grasshoper as well as to try to solve one of my own issues, which is more and more clients requesting multi-color prints and that means I have to change filament spools very often since these prints don't take much time. WORK IN PROGRESS Almost at the end of this design iteration I came up with two other ideas and designs that will require less parts. I will be working on them and testing. Please let me know any feedback or ideas that might apply, thanks :)

In addition to these printable parts it requires 2 bearings: OD 28mm, ID 12mm. The first bearing should be inserted into the part "DDSH-003" followed by "DDSH-003" and then the other bearing followed by the cap "DDSH-001".  
This requires 3 prints of "DDSH-005" which are the clamps that would expand into the spool. These will require a spring of 7mm diameter and about 30mm length.  
Once the spool holder is assembled the outer handle should contract the clamps allowing the easy removal of the pool.

I needed a way to mount a standard 5mm LED onto my "wearable" project (a Santa hat). I created this little sewable mount, and printed it with NinjaFlex (I used "Semitransparent White", http://www.adafruit.com/product/2445 printed at 100% fill). There's a groove inside to hold the ridge on a 5mm LED. The hole in the middle is tapered to ease insertion from the side with the mounting ears. These mounts are NOT designed for use with conductive thread. You'll have to use a more conventional wiring technique, like wire wrapping, soldering, or crimp connectors. By the way, the LED in the picture with 4 leads is an addressable LED, https://www.sparkfun.com/products/12986 that is compatible with Adafruit's Neopixels.

These parts are designed to be printed with NinjaFlex. I used
"Semitranslucent White", from Adafruit (www.adafruit.com)
PID# 2445. I used Cura as my slicer program, and used 100% fill
(hey, they're really small, so won't use much filament). These are designed to be mechanical mounts for a standard 5mm
LED. I'm using SparkFun COM-12986 "addressable" LEDs, compatible
with Adafruit's Neopixels, but they should work with any standard
5mm LED. THEY ARE NOT INTENDED FOR USE WITH CONDUCTIVE THREAD!
You'll have to figure out some other method for the electrical
connection, such as wirewrap or soldering to the LED leads. The mount has a groove in the middle for the ridge on the LED,
with a taper to ease insertion of the LED from the side that
has the mounting ears. The design has four ears that can be
sewn onto cloth. If you need fewer ears, you can either modify
the design or just trim the extras off with sciscors or a knife. I advise that you print one, and see if it needs to have the
size adjusted with the scaling factor in your slicer program.
If you need several, you may wish to print them several at a
time -- the time to clean the print bed is longer than the
actual print time for one. I've printed four at a time, and
although they come out rougher than printing one at a time,
they're quite usable, though need a little trimming with a
knife. I inserted the LED into the mount, then shoved the leads
through the cloth. I used a needle and ordinary thread to
sew the ears onto the cloth. Once I had all of my LEDs
mounted in this way, I soldered wires to them. (Since I wanted
high flexibility, I used silicone insulated stranded wire, such
as www.adafruit.com/products/2517 for black, and some other
colors.) A word on soldering technique: I normally wouldn't
recommend this technique (I've been soldering things for about
half a century), but as they say "if it's stupid, but it works,
it ain't stupid" (from the "rules of combat"). Spread out
the leads (especially if you have a four-lead LED). Then,
using a high-temperature soldering iron, tin each lead,
making sure you have a lot of solder on the lead. Tin the
stripped end of the wire to go onto the lead, slip some heat-
shrink tubing over the wire, then hold the wire to the lead
so it's in line with the lead, and heat both with the iron.
Hold the wire steady until the solder has solidified. (Under
"normal" conditions, I'd recommend twisting the wire around the
lead, then heat both with the soldering iron, and apply solder.
However, these aren't "normal" conditions.) I then slid the
heat-shrink tubing down to cover the lead, and "brushed" it
with the iron to get it to shrink down. I had 11 LEDs, each
with 4 leads, with power and ground "daisy chained", and data
wired from one to the next, with the cloth in question being
polyester, and had no sign of the cloth being damaged by the
heat. I also used a "cross tweezers", that is, tweezers you
squeeze to open, to hold the wires while soldering.

remixed_from.author: kai
remixed_from.title: Laser Pointer Holder for 40W CO2 Laser

title: Laser pointer for K40 Chinese CO2 Laser

description.text:
An adaptation/improvement on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53301 for my K40 cheap Chinese laser. This one is modified:
  • Clears the hinge/lips on my door (mine has a folded metal flange that tried to dislocate the original)
  • Steps back behind the mirror
  • Has a positive stop and a setscrew for angle, and has a spot for a ball-point-pen-spring instead of an external spring.
    • Like the other one, when you close the door, this lifts out of the way of the burning beam. Remember to hold it up if you're testing with the door open (you can see that I put binder clip on it if I'm aligning the mirrors)! I've also added (not pictured) an aluminum plate to protect the laser diode from the BFLaser in case I fire it without moving the arm out of the way. Oh, you want to download, separate, and print the "NoCase" file -- the "Case" file has a lot of blocks that I used to design it (eg a block for where the lid contacts the arm, a block for the plane the laser should be at, and a "keepout" area where the arm has to make a bend to not hit the mirror when it homes).

The laser is a cheap 6mm pointer module (http://amzn.to/1hP4OoM), You can see how it's laid out in my machine (the big "target" has a ridge that indicates where the laser should be). There's a small pocket in the arm and the hinge to accept a ball-point pen spring for a positive position when opened (you might need to file the arm/hinge just a bit so the action is smooth). There's also a 3mm hole for a setscrew if you nee to adjust the arm angle (since I made it for my machine, I don't ;) On my K40 unit, the L bend for the door this mounts to was not level/straight with the bed; a little finagling with a pair of vise-grips fixed that... No support is needed once you find which way to lay each piece -- the arm and the hinge both have flat sides, and my 3d printer didn't have a problem printing the post in the arm since it doesn't stick out very far. Remember to lift the arm out of the way if you're firing with the door open!

author: stufferooney

title: Yet another D-Link DSC Camera bracket for the Makergear M2

description.text:
This is a camera holder for the D-Link DSC Series of IP cameras
with a bracket that fits on a Makergear-M2. It may be placed in 2
positions (Vertical or horizontal) and slides in and out to "zoom".
It replaces the standard bracket and screws into the back of the
camera, which provides for swivel. The separate base of the
bracket could also be adapted for other mountings. There is a
screw hole to position and tighten the slide-out bracket. Also shared on Fusion 360, here: https://fusion360.autodesk.com/projects/yet-another-3d-printer-camera-bracket-for-makergear-and-d-link-dcs

Print both parts "vertical", no support is required - that is print with the
threads and hollow tube "up". To get the threads right I made a
"process" for the threaded portion and printed with a 1.5mm layer height. The remainder can be printed with any layer height. Any material
will do just fine.
There is a hole for a screw to hold the bracket - this can be self taped
or threaded with a tap.

author: CCVirginia

description.text:
About:
=====
3D printed case for the Proxmark3 - a software defined RFID reader swiss army knife. https://github.com/Proxmark/proxmark3 Files:
=====
case.stl - the bottom part of the case.
lid_print.stl - the lid and button
lid.stl - just the lid
button.stl - just the button. OpenSCAD files are included.

Print instructions:
=====
Print out case.stl as is. No support should be necessary. Print out lid_print.stl or lid.stl + button.stl. lid.scad will need flipping upside down if you want to print it, lid_print.stl has this done already. Personally I used black for the case, clear for the top so that the LEDs can still be seen and blue for the button, but it's your choice :) Fitting instructions:
===== Fit the edge of the board under the ridge on the far side then push down on the port side of the board to wedge the board into place. If it doesn't fit easily, lightly file the inside of the case and/or check your printer's calibration :) If you have difficulty getting one side of the lid in place - use a scraper or guitar pick between the snap and the slot while pushing down on the lid, then withdraw the scraper.

These are a left and right bracket to hold the Sainsmart LCD display.  
I designed them with DesignSpark Mechanical software (free download).

One problem I have consistently noticed with my filament is that every time the printer pulls some filament in, the spools rolls and keeps doing that until it falls of the table. To prevent that, the holder has a curve on the back which should stabilize the spool every time the printer pulls it in. This holder is very simple. The spool fits in the curve of the object which helps it spin easily and feed the printer without getting stuck. This print should print well, though it may take a while. Print 1 of each base and 4 wheels.
I created the base shape, then extruded the pipes to fit inside each other. Then I created 4 rollers to help the filament movement.

This spool holder is designed like a modular rack, you can to put many spools as you want in vertical form.

This model have two options to being used:
  • You can put the modular rack on a table or in the floor.

  • A filament guide (1.75mm and 3mm)

remixed_from.author: wanderermg
remixed_from.title: Samsung Galaxy Nexus car holder v.2

title: Galaxy Nexus Improved Holder & Tripod Mount

description.text:
I needed to mount my Galaxy Nexus on a tripod for filming, and decided to make a suitable mount with inspiration from existing mounts on Thingiverse.  
I printed the original holder and found that it did not hug the phone that well. I extended the vertical holders and added clips to them so they actually snap over the phone. To facilitate this I also added release tabs on top.  
Another issue was the interference of one of the support arms with the volume buttons. My solution was to move the one vertical holder over a bit. This means it now needs support to be printed but it still turned out great.  
The final improvement was to make an opening in the back for the camera lens and flash LED.  
The tripod mount disconnects from the back so I can design future mounts for the holder itself. The mount itself was made to fit a few tripods I had laying around, and I'm not sure if it's a standard size. The original SketchUp file is included in case anyone needs to modify it.

Make sure to print the "GNEX_Vertical_Clip_1.stl" on its side with supports.  
I also printed the "GNEX_Main_Holder.stl" with supports so the camera hole wouldn't collapse.   
Some #8-32 screws were used with washers and nuts to assemble the holder, although I believe it was originally made for metric screws. The captive nut holes fit the thin #8 nuts I had perfectly, so I didn't change any dimensions related to the fasteners.

If you need to align one shaft very precisely with another some distance away, this device can do so very well. It uses a small off-the-shelf, $20 laser from Amazon: http://amzn.to/1g4Jx9C And a regular CR2032 battery to power it: http://amzn.to/1UBTjO0 (disclosure: Amazon affiliate links) To assemble, bolt it onto your shaft. Use some scotch tape to tape the bare wire leads to the battery, and insert the battery in the slot from the top, followed by the laser. The hole is the exact size of the laser module, so it should fit in there very snugly, very securely, and very concentrically. The laser will be on permanently at this point, until the tape is removed. Rotate the shaft slowly and let the laser hit a wall or whatever far away, say 20' or so. The top of the authenticator is connected to the mounting plate by a thing neck which strikes a balance between rigidity and flexibility. Using the top four bolts, the laser can be angled very precisely on that neck with respect to the base-plate and shaft. As the shaft spins, the laser will trace a circular path when out of alignment with its shaft. Notice as it spins which side the laser runs out on and, on the four top bolts, loosen that bolt a bit and tighten the other side to flex the laser a bit in the other direction. Continue adjusting the 1/4" tension bolts in this fashion until it remains just a point as it is rotated. The joint on the bottom acts like a wobble plate, allowing the laser to be minutely adjusted to within millionths of an arc-second, depending on distance. The fact that the point of the laser is shining on something far away means that you can get it incredibly-well aligned to the shaft. With the laser now well-aligned to your shaft, you can align your shaft to the axis of rotation of a bearing system, or another shaft, with extreme precision, which will allow you to eliminate both vertical, horizontal, and angular misalignment. It uses 5/16" screws for the mount, and 1/4"-28 for the wobble-plate.

author: Ninjaneer

description.text:
Designed to replace a store-bought handle bar mount that could support a device w/a 1/4"-20 threaded nut. After buying 2 of them and having both of them break on me, I decided it would be fun to recreate the mount but make a few improvements, which include:
  • Reinforcing the areas that were susceptible to breaking because they had very thin walls.
  • Increased the size of the thumbscrew that tightens the ball-joint to make it easier to adjust the angle and un/tighten.

Print all the parts once. Use this info as a guideline:
  • Print each in the orientation in the STLs.
    • Top Mount will need support. Make sure to add support to the arch and the area around the joints.
    • Ball Joint will need either: manual supports (Simplify3D), a raft, or a brim in addition to supports to keep it from popping off the plate.
  • Use 3 shells and at least 30-50% infill. The big thumbscrew needs at least 50%.
  • I used PETG plastic for a stronger/heat resistant part. It'll print well in PLA and can be strong... just won't hold up over hours of hot TX summer heat.

• 1 1/2" section of 1/4"-20 threaded rod (I dremel'd off the head of a 1/4"-20 screw)
  • 2x 1/4"-20 nut (1 is just used for assembly)
  • M4x40 socket head screw
  • 2x M4 nut
  • 1/16" nail or rivet - cut to 24mm
  • Gorilla glue
  • a 1" wide strip of rubber to use on the handle bars to restrict the mount from slipping.

• Clean up the ball on the ball joint part by removing all support material. Don't worry about making the bottom of the ball perfect. Don't over polish/smooth the ball. Some friction is required to allow it to be locked in place.
  • Take the 1/4"-20 threaded section and add 2 nuts on the end that will be exposed for mounting a device. Tighten the 2 nuts against each other to lock them in place. This will give us leverage to get the threaded rod screwed in.
  • Add some Gorilla glue inside the top of the ball joint that will receive the 1/4"-20 threaded rod. This will be used to lock the threaded rod in place.
  • Screw the threaded rod into the top of the ball joint. Use the 2 nuts to tighten the rod all the way down the hole (12mm). Set aside and allow to dry.
  • With the smaller thumbscrew, add a small amount of gorilla glue along the outer wall of the hole for the nut. Place the nut in the hole and tape it down (or put a weight on the thumbscrew/nut. Gorilla glue foams to conform to the area it's bonding, so you need to keep the nut from being pushed out. Set aside to dry.
  • Join the top/bottom clamp pieces. Take the 24mm length of nail/rivet and insert thru holes in joints. Use a 1/16" drillbit to clean the holes to make it easier to insert.
  • Insert one M4 nut into the top opening on the Top Clamp.
  • Insert the other M4 nut on to the top of the knob.
  • Insert the M4x40mm screw thru the Knob and tighten to M4 nut.
  • Insert the completed knob thru the bottom part of the clamp to tighten with the top clamp.
  • Once the ball joint is dry, remove the 2 nuts from the threaded rod. Loosen them against each other to remove.
  • Carefully (very carefully) insert the ball joint into the top post on the clamp. This is a very tight fit which will require a slow/delicate insertion so you don't break the threaded walls. The walls will flex out a bit to allow the ball to seat fully in place.
  • Insert the large thumbscrew over the ball joint and tighten. It might be easier to add a lubricate to the thumbscrew before tightening to help against plastic-on-plastic friction.
  • Add the small thumbscrew to the threaded rod.
    • Additionally, I glued a small round piece of rubber to the top of the smaller thumbscrew to help in keeping things from moving.

An exploded buckyball.
Serves no apparent purpose - just tinkering with scad and geometry.

Use the customiser to generate one core segment, one hexagonal segment and one pentagonal segment.   
Then print 1x core, 20x hexagons and 12x pentagons. Print the hex and pentagons hollow to save time, plastic and let light through. The core probably needs some infill to work properly, 15% works fine.  
Put a blob of glue in each of the holes in the core (something simple like Loctite All Purpose works fine) and insert the hex and pentagonal segments.  
If you're averse to glue, you could probably tinker with the scad and enable the balls at the top of the pentagonal and hexagonal pieces to make it simply click together. Thought of that one a bit late, but I'd imagine it would work if you get the tolerances right.

title: A 90 degree frame bracket for an artists canvas

description.text:
We actually designed this for making a canvas frame to contain some acoustic foam panels and cover them in material. This is for a large sound deadening panel for our conference room, which is a bit echo-y.  
There are three versions - a Left and Right hand with a hanging hole, and a version with no hole.

If printed in PLA you'll get a slightly more rigid product, but works on ABS as well. It can withstand printing at 0.3mm and one perimeter so each one takes about an hour on our Robox with the 0.8mm nozzle.

comments.text: Very difficult to print. A lot of "warping". PLA or ABS.
comments.author: Hautcastel

comments.text: The one in the picture is ABS and to be fair it did lift a bit on the base. The right angle is preserved though so still performs its function. I've printed others in PLA since and they are fine: no lifting of warping at all.

A tool holder/caddy for the work bench.
I designed this to hold the tools a gunsmith would commonly use when working on pistols(1911A1). Punches, screwdrivers, caliper, gun cleaning tooth brush, allen wrenches etc. the hooks on the front are spaced for a 1911A1 bushing wrench. You can personalize it in tinkercad just ungroup and change the text. Made this with tinkercad. Enjoy!

6/19/13 moved the position of the tool hooks and made them a bit bigger to hold two tools instead of the one, be careful when you add helper disks for printing, the new slicer does wierd things to your print, I will try printing the top again with rafts instead.  
6/11/13 reposted with the complete design and three seperate files for the components. print parts seperately and assemble with ABS Glue.  
6/11/13 Printed this way too much support material and 12 hour print..... I will repost the parts for this as to not waste filament when printing should also speed printing.  
6/10/13 First print 80% complete and it started to curl in one of the corners near the print head........aborted will try again.  
Plans are to print with 5 shells and 25% fill, may have to rotate on the build plate to minimize support material. will report back after I have it printed.

Hi there, This is my second attempt at building a tricopter. First version took ages to print and wasn't worth to share... This one gives quite a satisfactory flying feeling... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4uo8sGndtDg https://instagram.com/p/7DmLaZJe2i/ Here is the stuff I used to assemble it:
  • 2204 motor (3)
  • 12 A ESC (3)
  • 6X4.5 Prop (3)
  • 155X10mm hollow aluminum rod (2)
  • 255X10mm hollow aluminum rod (1)
  • 37X5 mm spacers (Diatone)
  • Ball bearing 5mm/2.5mm (2) & 2.5 mm screw (2) (Those are used to assemble the rear motor mount)
  • CC3D (fits any FC of the same size... like NAZE32)
  • RX
  • Micro-servo (1) (servo arm & small stuff needed to attach it to the motor mount)
  • 3S 1300/1800 mA battery
  • a few M3 screws & nuts, plastic clamps and velcro...
    • You'll also find the file for a Fatshark 600 TVL FPV camera mount. (speaking about FPV, I strap my video RX on the rear leg of the tricopter...) Keep also in mind that the front plates of the body feature holes you could use to mount your own custom cam mount... (The mount for the hummingbird cam you can see on the picture is not available... this one doesn't work really well...) I recommend medium infills for all the parts except for the legs that are kind of disposable (light infills)... The whole stuff is designed to be quickly reprinted in case you need spare parts... The legs are designed to snap away when crashing... you just need to clip them on the arms and put a tiny drop of glue to make sure they stay in place while flying... If you're more interested in this thingie, I'll keep the original 123design files available to you! Cheers!

• Clip the 2 ball bearings on each side of the TAIL_TRICO part. Stick the 2.5mm screws inside the bearing. Take TAIL_M_TRICO part, and screw the 2.5mm screws into it. This will make your hinge of your motor mount.

  • Put the BODY1_TRICO part and the 2 FRONT_ARM_TRICO on a flat surface. Attached these part using the 2 155X10mm aluminum rods. The rods are supposed to clip to the parts. Once in place, use a tiny drop of cyanoacrylate glue to keep everything in place. Use a precision multitool to bore the holes in the rods using the printed part as guide. Use 3mm screws and nuts in the holes you just did.

  • Fit the remaining 255X10mm aluminum rod inside the tail you assembled. (Still using a drop of glue, multitool and 3mm screws&nuts). Fit the tail in the body, attached it the same way. Try to keep the front motor mount, the body and the tail perfectly flat& aligned…

  • Put the 6 37X5mm aluminum spacers in the BODY1_TRICO part, used M3 screws to attach it.

  • Place your flight controller and rx stuff on the BODY2_TRICO part… Attach it to the aluminum spacer to using M3 screws.

  • (FYI, there is enough room in the body to fit the 2 front ESCs)

  • Clip the legs of the drone on the arms and tail. Use a tiny drop of glue to make sure they don’t move while flying.
    • And this is it… I assume that you know how to wire a multicopter, how to use a servo and how to program a FC… I leave the rest to you!!! Although, If you have any question feel free to message me!

description.text:
I needed to make a cedar fence section with a particular look, and making a jig to get the slats evenly spaced was a perfect excuse to play with my Replicator 2!  
As configured, the jig can hold a slat about 5/8" wide and space them 4" apart. Multiple jigs can be connected end-to-end to layout sections of arbitrary size. The built-in spring applies enough pressure to hold everything in place while gluing, which really helps!.  
The scad file is included and should be customizable for other spacings without too much difficulty.

The jig prints just fine on my Replicator 2 with medium quality. I printed a couple dozen of them and the only failures were due to the occasional piece not sticking to the build platform.  
I made the jig all one piece to keep it simple, but that means there is a small post printing procedure required. The gripper won't always slide freely because it contains a pretty long bridge that can sag a little during printing and stick to the center track.  
You can break it free pretty easily by turning the jig upside down and pushing the bottom of the gripper up with your thumb, while pinching down on the top with your fingers. It'll make a very satisfying snapping sound when it pops loose. Doing one side of the track at a time makes it little easier.
